title: How does classical music help make you smarter? - Quora

response.answer_text: I don’t think it makes people smarter intellectually, BUT I do believe it may score some points with whomever hears a person stepping outside of their usual musical tastes. Trying to impress someone with how intelligent one is is one of the most difficult tricks to accomplish - if the person knows more about the subject - or realizes you don’t know anything about it - say goodbye to that phone number/job/etc. you were hoping to get! Yes, I know I just said something really really shallow. Trying to impress when looking for a date is quite shallow (it sounds like someone isn’t confident in their own abilities) and attempting to get a job, well, I’ve never done that for an interview so I don’t know if it is done! Still…people think others think too much about other people (yeah, good luck figuring out that phrase - I typed it and it’s giving me trouble! If anyone knows how to translate that I beg you to do so) when most folks are too caught up in their own misgivings and low self opinions to think about how “smart” someone is. Plus I wonder how many people, when listening to someone exercise their brains think, “Wow! They’re so smart! I’m way out of their league so I better just leave them alone and let them find someone who’s as smart as they are!” I have a reputation among my friends for being tangential. I am also kind of a joke savant. I say these things to warn you all of the joke of which this question reminds me: Did you know beer makes you smarter? It made Bud wiser. Apologies.

There's very little scientific support for the theory that listening to classical music makes you smarter. But making the leap for the moment that there's some truth in it, I would hazard a guess that by “classical” most people mean “symphonic” music (i.e. music played by an orchestra), and so the complexity and variety of the timbres produced by a whole orchestra of instruments playing together and in various combinations is stimulating to the brain’s neural pathways and promotes the visualization of the music - because most symphonic music is instrumental, our mind tends to invent a “story” to tie in with the music - like a film score. That process of “imagineering” worlds based on music, creates new neural pathways and could make the brain more adept at creative thought. It's only a model - there's so far no proof that listening to classical music is any more effective at this than listening to rap or pop music, so we need to prove the adage first.
